sources.title: Outside The Law
sources.description: Outside the Law is a 1920 crime film directed by Tod Browning. Browning remade the film in 1930. Black Mike (Lon Chaney) is a despicable gangster who lures Molly (Priscilla Dean), the daughter of a San Francisco underworld leader, back to a life of crime. Mike frames Molly's father for murder and then plots to double-cross her as well. But Molly's hard heart is slowly melted by her gangster lover. The film ends with in a climactic shootout. The print in a little murky so some title cards are difficult to read. Adjusting contrast should fix this.

Outside the Law (1920) is an American silent crime drama directed by Tod Browning and produced by Universal Pictures during the golden years of early Hollywood. Starring Priscilla Dean, Lon Chaney, and Wheeler Oakman, this film explores betrayal, morality, and the search for redemption within the gritty world of San Franciscoâ€™s Chinatown. This restored and colorized edition revives a groundbreaking classic that helped define the crime genre and cement Lon Chaneyâ€™s reputation as one of cinemaâ€™s most versatile actors.

Plot Summary:
The story centers on Molly Madden, known as "Silky Moll" (Priscilla Dean), the daughter of gangster Silent Madden (Ralph Lewis). After a life steeped in crime, she is influenced by Chang Lo (E. Alyn Warren), a wise Confucian philosopher who urges her to leave her criminal path behind. Silky tries to reform, but her past comes back to haunt her when she and her partner Dapper Bill Ballard (Wheeler Oakman) become entangled in a heist.

Standing in their way is Black Mike Sylva (Lon Chaney), a ruthless gangster who seeks to destroy Molly and reclaim dominance in the underworld. Chaneyâ€™s portrayal of Sylva is one of his most chilling early performances, embodying greed and brutality. His role contrasts with that of Chang Lo, whose teachings about honesty and morality underscore the filmâ€™s deeper message.

As betrayal and greed spiral into violence, Molly faces a choice between staying in the world of crime or embracing redemption. The climactic scenes deliver a mix of suspense and moral reckoning, making Outside the Law one of the first Hollywood films to explore the psychological dimensions of crime rather than simply glorifying it.

Film Significance:
Outside the Law is historically important as one of Tod Browningâ€™s earliest collaborations with Lon Chaney, predating their later masterpieces The Unholy Three (1925) and the legendary Dracula (1931). The film was groundbreaking for presenting Chinese characters in a dignified and philosophical light, which was highly unusual for its time in Hollywood.

Chaneyâ€™s dual performance as both the villainous Black Mike Sylva and the Chinese servant Ah Wing demonstrated his early mastery of makeup and character transformation, earning him recognition as the "Man of a Thousand Faces." Priscilla Dean, meanwhile, was one of Universalâ€™s biggest stars in the 1920s, and this film solidified her reputation as a leading actress in crime and melodrama stories.
